questions.q: If A = {1, 2} and B = {x, y}, then the Cartesian product A × B has:
questions.explanation: A×B consists of all ordered pairs (a,b) with a∈A and b∈B: (1,x),(1,y),(2,x),(2,y).

questions.q: If f: ℝ → ℝ is defined by f(x) = x^3 − 3x and g(x) = x + 2, then (f ∘ g)(1) equals:
The function f(x) = 2x + 3 has inverse function:
questions.explanation: Solve y = 2x + 3 for x: x = (y − 3)/2. So f⁻¹(x) = (x − 3)/2.

questions.q: For which function is f⁻¹(x) = f(x)?
questions.explanation: The identity f(x)=x is its own inverse (f(f(x)) = x). (1/x is also its own inverse on domain ℝ\{0}, but the standard answer here is f(x)=x.)

questions.q: Let D(x) mean 'x is a doctor' and H(x) mean 'x works in a hospital'. What is the symbolic form of 'Not all doctors work in hospitals'?
questions.explanation: Negating 'all doctors work in hospitals' gives ∃x(D(x) ∧ ¬H(x)). That is equivalent to ¬∀x(D(x)→H(x)), so both b and c hold.

questions.q: If C(x) means 'x is a car' and F(x) means 'x is fast', which symbolizes 'Only fast vehicles are cars'?
questions.explanation: 'Only fast vehicles are cars' means 'If something is a car, then it is fast' — i.e., ∀x(C(x) → F(x)).

questions.q: Let P(x,y) mean 'x is greater than y'. What is the meaning of ∀x ∃y P(x,y)?
questions.explanation: ∀x∃y P(x,y) says: for each x there exists a y such that P(x,y) holds, i.e., x > y for that y.
options: For every x, there is some y that is greater than x
For every x, there is some y that x is greater than
There exists an x that is greater than all y
There exists a y that is greater than all x

questions.q: If P(x) means 'x is a prime number' and Q(x) means 'x is odd', which statement means 'Some prime numbers are not odd'?
questions.explanation: There exists a prime x such that x is not odd: ∃x(P(x) ∧ ¬Q(x)) (example: 2).

questions.q: If P(x) means 'x is a student' and Q(x) means 'x studies hard', what does ∃x(P(x) ∧ Q(x)) mean in English?
questions.explanation: The existential quantifier says at least one x is a student who studies hard → 'some students study hard.'

questions.q: Let P(x) be 'x is a positive number' and Q(x) be 'x is less than 10'. Which statement represents 'All positive numbers less than 10 are integers'?
questions.explanation: The universal conditional says: for every x, if x is positive and less than 10, then x is an integer (R(x)).

questions.q: If P(x) is 'x speaks French' and Q(x) is 'x knows Python', what is the logical equivalent of ¬∀x (P(x) → Q(x))?
questions.explanation: Negating ∀x(P→Q) gives ∃x¬(P→Q) which is ∃x(P ∧ ¬Q): there exists someone who speaks French and does not know Python.
options: Everyone speaks French and knows Python.
There is someone who speaks French but does not know Python.
There is someone who does not speak French and knows Python.
Everyone who knows Python does not speak French.

questions.q: Let C(x) be 'computer x is connected to the network' and V(x,y) be 'computer x has a virus from computer y.' Which expression represents: 'There is a computer on the network that has not received a virus from any other computer'?
questions.explanation: We want an x that is connected AND for every y it has not got a virus from y: ∃x [C(x) ∧ ∀y ¬V(x,y)].

questions.q: Let L(x,y) be 'x loves y.' What does the following statement mean? ∃x (L(x, Logic) ∧ ∀y ((y ≠ x) → ¬L(y, Logic)))
questions.explanation: There exists an x who loves Logic and no other y (y≠x) loves Logic — exactly one person loves Logic.
options: Everyone loves Logic except one person.
Someone loves Logic and Logic loves no one.
There is a person who loves only Logic.

questions.q: Express 'The sum of two positive integers is always positive' using quantifiers over the domain of Integers ℤ.
questions.explanation: The property must hold for all integers x and y: if x>0 and y>0 then x+y>0, so ∀x∀y((x>0∧y>0)→(x+y>0)).

questions.q: Let P(x) be a predicate. Which statement is logically equivalent to ¬∃x ∀y (P(x) ∨ P(y))?
questions.explanation: Negate quantifiers stepwise: ¬∃x∀y(...) ≡ ∀x¬∀y(...) ≡ ∀x∃y¬(P(x)∨P(y)) ≡ ∀x∃y(¬P(x)∧¬P(y)).

questions.q: Let W(x,y) mean person x works for company y. Translate: 'No one works for every company.'
questions.explanation: There does not exist a person who works for every company: ¬∃x ∀y W(x,y).

questions.q: Analyze the logical steps: ∀x(P(x) → Q(x)), ¬Q(a), P(a) → Q(a) [Rule X], ¬P(a) [Rule Y]. Identify Rule X and Rule Y.
questions.explanation: Instantiate the universal ∀x for 'a' (Universal Instantiation), then use Modus Tollens on P(a)→Q(a) and ¬Q(a) to get ¬P(a).
options: X: Universal Generalization, Y: Modus Ponens
X: Universal Instantiation, Y: Modus Tollens
X: Existential Instantiation, Y: Modus Tollens
X: Universal Instantiation, Y: Disjunctive Syllogism

questions.q: To prove 'For all integers n, if n^2 is odd then n is odd' using Proof by Contraposition, what is the correct initial assumption?
questions.explanation: Contraposition assumes the negation of the conclusion: assume n is even, then show n^2 is even, which proves the original implication.
options: Assume n is odd, and n^2 is even

questions.q: Identify the logical structure of the following proof attempt for the statement (P ∧ Q) → R: 'Suppose ¬R is true. We demonstrate that this implies ¬P ∨ ¬Q.'
questions.explanation: Showing ¬R → (¬P ∨ ¬Q) is proving the contrapositive of (P ∧ Q) → R, so it's a proof by contraposition.

questions.q: Determine the negation of the statement: 'There is a student in the class who has taken every course offered.'
questions.explanation: Negating ∃x ∀y T(x,y) becomes ∀x ∃y ¬T(x,y): for every student there exists at least one course they haven't taken.
options: Every student in the class has taken every course offered.
There is a student who has not taken any course offered.
For every student, there is a course they have not taken.
No student has taken any course.
